title: Note 1 - Reinforcement learning (Section 1 & 2)
text:
â¬… Back

Section 1.1 - Basic concepts
Illustrative example: Grid-world

Accessible / forbidden / target cells

State
The status of the agent with respect to the environment.
For Grid-world, state refers to the position.
Action
An action leads to a change in state, for example:
\[
s_1 \xrightarrow{a_2} s_2
\]
Forbidden area
Entering it will result in a penalty.
Policy
Provides a recommendation for which action to take given a state, e.g., choosing aâ‚ or aâ‚‚.
For example:
\[
p(s_2 \mid s_1, a_2) = 1
\]
This means that the policy for transitioning from sâ‚ to sâ‚‚ must use action aâ‚‚.
Reward
A real number providing feedback on the choices already made.

Greater than 0 (> 0) indicates encouragement

Less than 0 (< 0) indicates punishment
It helps the agent reduce the tendency to enter forbidden areas.

Trajectory
A sequence of state-action-reward transitions.
The return is the sum of the rewards collected along the trajectory. By comparing the return values of different trajectories, we can determine which overall policy performs better.
Discounted return
By applying the discount factor Î³, we can place more emphasis on either short-term or long-term rewards.
Episode
When the number of states is finite, the resulting trajectory is referred to as an episode.
Markov Decision Process
Most importantly, the next decision is not influenced by previous decisions, which is known as the property of being memoryless.


Section 1.2 - Connection
These concepts are interconnected. The transition from one state to another, which generates a reward, is illustrated in Figure 1.

Image source: Shiyu Zhao, Westlake University
The accumulation of multiple states, forming a Trajectory (or Episode), and eventually leading to a return is shown in Figure 2.

Image source: Shiyu Zhao, Westlake University


Section 2 - Bellman Equation
Bootstrapping
The value of a state depends on the estimated values of subsequent states.

Return
The cumulative sum of rewards collected over time, representing the long-term value of a trajectory.

It is the total discounted reward from a given state, considering both immediate and future rewards.
Mathematically, it is defined as:
\[
G_t = R_{t+1} + \gamma R_{t+2} + \gamma^2 R_{t+3} + \dots
\]
\[
G_t = R_{t+1} + \gamma (R_{t+2} + \gamma R_{t+3} + \dots)
\]
\[
G_t = R_{t+1} + \gamma G_{t+1}
\]


State Value && Bellman Equation
In reinforcement learning, the state value refers to the expected return starting from a given state, following a particular policy.

It quantifies how good it is for the agent to be in a state ( s ).
Formally defined as:
\[
v_\pi(s) = \mathbb{E}_{\pi}\left[G_t \mid s_t = s\right]
\]
which can be expressed as:
\[
v_\pi(s) = \mathbb{E}[R_{t+1} + \gamma G_{t+1} \mid S_t = s]
\]
\[  
v_\pi(s) = \sum_{a} \pi(a|s) \left[ \sum_{r} p(r|s,a) r + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,a) v_\pi(s') \right]
\]


Matrix Form of Bellman Equation
The Bellman equation in matrix form can be written as:
\[
\mathbf{v_\pi} = \mathbf{R_\pi} + \gamma \mathbf{P_\pi} \mathbf{v_\pi}
\] 
Image source: Shiyu Zhao, Westlake University

Action Value Function
State value represents the expected long-term return an agent will receive starting from a state, while following a specific policy.
Action value represents the expected long-term return an agent will receive after taking a specific action in a state, and then continuing to follow a specific policy.

P1 Harmful / Jailbreak Suppression
ğŸŸ¨ ARUA-VL. Suppress toxic neurons to reduce harmful generation; includes dynamic activation editing. Refs: Whispering Experts: Neural Interventions for Toxicity Mitigation in Language Models (AurA), arXiv 2024, Finding Safety Neurons in LLMs (OpenReview 2024)
Baseline: JailBreakV-28K: A Benchmark for Assessing the Robustness of MultiModal LLMs against Jailbreak Attacks (arXiv 2024). In the fields of text and MLLM, jailbreaks are generated through inductive prompts, and a lot has already been done in this area, making it difficult to achieve breakthroughs.
HCOT focus: build harmful-vs-safe CoT preference pairs; train with DPO (ICLR 2024) or GRPO (arXiv 2024); compare with RLHF baselines.


P2 Multimodal / Video Safety (Temporal Triggers)
ğŸ”„ Extension of P1-A: apply toxic-neuron suppression methods at the frame/shot level in videos. Detect & suppress dangerous activations using P1-Aâ€™s activation-intervention toolkit; This work should be carried out after the completion of P1-A.
ğŸŸ¨ Planned harmful multimodal video dataset; inspired by Video-SafetyBench (arXiv 2025), SafeVid-350K (arXiv 2025). At the video level, several toxic video datasets have already emerged. I have some ideas about generating harmful videos using large models, and this will be a key direction for the next stage of work.
Video CoT refusal + RL: Apply reinforcement learning based on key video frames/features to fine-tune MLLMs and reduce harmful video generation. Use per-frame reasoning chains with trigger timestamps; optimize with Safe-RLHF-V (arXiv 2025).


P3 Hallucination / Factual Errors
Evidence: NAM â€“ Neuron Attribution for MLLMs (NeurIPS 2024), enabling analysis of â€œhallucination clusters.â€ and searching for neuron models prone to hallucinations.
This requires further research.
CoT Ã— RL alignment: Use DPO/GRPO or RLHF variants to prefer evidence-based refusal or factual CoTs over hallucinated outputs. Grounding refs: SelfCheckGPT (ACL 2023), RAHF: Reinforced Alignment for Hallucination Factuality (arXiv 2023).


P4 Multilingual / Cultural Contexts
It is possible to analyze the perception abilities of different neurons in large models across different languages.
Gap: multilingual jailbreak/red-team datasets (subtitle corruption, cultural memes).
A future direction is to conduct comparative studies on how chain-of-thought reasoning and reinforcement learning guide content across different cultural contexts, such as Chinese, Japanese, and English.



Note: The experimental part of AURA-VL has already been completed. I will begin writing the paper in the near future, with the plan to submit it to the target journal.

title: EX 1 - VERL_PPO
text:
â¬… Back

Reproducing VERL PPO with Pods
In this experiment, I learned how to reproduce the PPO algorithm from the VERL framework inside Pods.
My main idea is to design a custom reward model to reduce the generation of toxic content.
The overall framework is based on DAPO, so I first need to reproduce VERL.


Using Pods
VERL depends on Docker, but Docker is not supported on Autodl.
So I used Pods for remote SSH connection.
Advantages:
1. We can connect to a pre-installed Docker environment:
whatcanyousee/verl:ngc-cu124-vllm0.8.3-sglang0.4.5-mcore0.12.0-te2.2
2. No need for Xshell â€“ Pods provide a built-in terminal.
3. Many available GPUs (like A100) at a reasonable price.
4. Model download is fast and efficient.


Install VERL

After pulling the Docker image, it will create a container under /workspace.

Inside the container, install the latest nightly version of VERL:

git clone https://github.com/volcengine/verl && cd verl


PPO Test

Download and preprocess the GSM8K dataset:

python3 examples/data_preprocess/gsm8k.py --local_dir ~/data/gsm8k

Download pretrained model weights:

python3 -c "import transformers; transformers.pipeline('text-generation', model='Qwen/Qwen2.5-0.5B-Instruct')"

Run PPO training with a rule-based reward model:

PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1 python3 -m verl.trainer.main_ppo \
 data.train_files=$HOME/data/gsm8k/train.parquet \
 data.val_files=$HOME/data/gsm8k/test.parquet \
 data.train_batch_size=256 \
 data.max_prompt_length=512 \
 data.max_response_length=256 \
 actor_rollout_ref.model.path=Qwen/Qwen2.5-0.5B-Instruct \
 actor_rollout_ref.actor.optim.lr=1e-6 \
 actor_rollout_ref.actor.ppo_mini_batch_size=64 \
 actor_rollout_ref.actor.ppo_micro_batch_size_per_gpu=4 \
 actor_rollout_ref.rollout.log_prob_micro_batch_size_per_gpu=8 \
 actor_rollout_ref.rollout.tensor_model_parallel_size=1 \
 actor_rollout_ref.rollout.gpu_memory_utilization=0.4 \
 actor_rollout_ref.ref.log_prob_micro_batch_size_per_gpu=4 \
 critic.optim.lr=1e-5 \
 critic.model.path=Qwen/Qwen2.5-0.5B-Instruct \
 critic.ppo_micro_batch_size_per_gpu=4 \
 algorithm.kl_ctrl.kl_coef=0.001 \
 trainer.logger=['console'] \
 trainer.val_before_train=False \
 trainer.default_hdfs_dir=null \
 trainer.n_gpus_per_node=1 \
 trainer.nnodes=1 \
 trainer.save_freq=10 \
 trainer.test_freq=10 \
 trainer.total_epochs=15 2>&1 | tee verl_demo.log


Experimental Results
The experiment successfully ran with a single-card PPO, with approximately 20GB of GPU memory usage. Next, I will attempt to reproduce DAPO and GRPO, and promptly review literature on custom reward functions to apply new ideas to DAPO/GRPO.

Research Motivation
Since 2022, I have been dedicated to researching various forms of toxic speech, including hate speech, offensive language, and patronizing and condescending language (PCL). This line of research includes the construction of a PCL dataset (NLPCCâ€™23), an LLM-based PCL detector (EMNLPâ€™24), and the multimodal PCL detection (ICASSPâ€™25).
My research is driven by the goal of protecting vulnerable groups from toxic online discourse and investigating novel cybersecurity paradigms in the context of LLMs/MLLMs.
